discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Search rules in Cisco Expressway are used to define different regulations based on the protocol (e.g., SIP or H.323) or the source of the query. Search rules are essential for controlling how incoming and outgoing calls are routed based on various criteria, such as the type of protocol used, the calling or called party, or the source of the call request.

questions.question_text: Which dial plan settings can be used to set up different regulations according to the protocol (SIP or H.323) or the source of the query?
When external video endpoints are called via a DNS zone, which dialing method requires DNS to be configured in the Expressway server?

choices.A: Call History Configuration > Call Policy > Rules

questions.question_text: A company has a single Expressway-E that exhibits high resource utilization. An engineer checks the logs and finds numerous fraudulent attempts from sip:200@cisco.com. Where must the engineer go to configure a call policy rule and block the desired URI?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Given the options provided, A is the closest to being correct, as it mentions the use of UDP for media transmission, but it does not fully capture the multiplexing aspect accurately.

Select Answer A

The default media traversal port range is 36000 to 59999, and is set on the Expressway-C at Configuration > Local Zones > Traversal Subzone. In Large Expressway systems the first 12 ports in the range – 36000 to 36011 by default – are always reserved for multiplexed traffic. The Expressway-E listens on these ports. You cannot configure a distinct range of demultiplex listening ports on Large systems: they always use the first 6 pairs in the media port range. On Small/Medium systems you can explicitly specify which 2 ports listen for multiplexed RTP/RTCP traffic, on the Expressway-E (Configuration > Traversal > Ports). If you choose not to configure a particular pair of ports (Use configured demultiplexing ports = No), then the Expressway-E will listen on the first pair of ports in the media traversal port range (36000 and 36001 by default).

Selected Answer: A
I would think also A

Media Demultiplexing
The Expressway-E uses media demultiplexing in the following call scenarios:

Any H.323 or SIP call leg to/from an Expressway-C through a traversal zone configured to use Assent.

Any H.323 call leg to/from an Expressway-C through a traversal server zone configured to use H460.19 in demultiplexing mode.

H.323 call legs between an Expressway-E and an Assent or H.460.19 enabled endpoint.

comments.content: i would go for A because there are two sockets open not only one for both RTP and RTCP

questions.question_text: How do the Cisco Expressway-C and Expressway-E servers transmit media to each other?

choices.A: RTP and RTCP are multiplexed for all internal and external video endpoints across the traversal link using UDP.
choices.B: When the Expressway-C receives RTP and RTCP media, it establishes a new UDP socket with the Expressway-E.
choices.D: When the Expressway-E receives RTP and RTCP media, it establishes a new UDP socket with the Expressway-C.
choices.C: RTP and RTCP are multiplexed for all internal and external video endpoints across the traversal link using TLS.

comments.content: When u need to configure connection between 2 Expressways C u can only create neighbor zone - not traversal not transform but neighbor zone

questions.question_text: An engineer must enable the communication between two separate Expressway-C servers to allow inbound and outbound calling between different endpoints registered on each server. Which configuration must happen?

choices.A: Configure a traversal zone on each server with a destination of the other Expressway-C.
choices.D: Configure a transform on each server to convert the calling alias into the called alias.
choices.B: Configure a neighbor zone on each server with a destination of the other Expressway-C.
choices.C: Configure a transform on each server to strip the port numbers at the end of the alias.
